_prev_prog_3.Description:
The following elements are required prevention program components of OSHA?s PSM directive and Program Level 3 for covered processes as defined by 40 CFR Part 68.48.  All covered processes at Smokehouse Compressor Facility is managed as Program Level 3, under the PSM and RMP regulations.

The Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.  With regard to trade secrets, a SOP has not been included as part of the Prevention Program.



Employee Participation

Employers must develop a written plan of action describing how they will consult with their employees on hazard analysis and other elements of PSM/RMP.  Employers must also provide access to all relevant PSM/RMP information to its employees.

The full requirements for employee participation are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(c) and 40 CFR Part 68.83 and the Company?s Compliance Program, Management and Employee Commitment.



Process Safety Information

Employers must maintain written Process Safety Information (PSI) pertaining to the hazardous chemicals used in the covered process that includes toxicity information, Permissible Exposure Levels (PELs), physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data, and hazardous effects from mixing.  Some of this information can be in the form of Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) that meet the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.1200 (g).

Employers must also maintain written PSI pertaining to the technology of the covered process that includes Process Flow Diagrams (PFD), process chemistry, safe upper and lower operating limits, maximum intended inventory, and the consequences of process deviation.

In addition, detailed written PSI must be maintained for process equipment (e.g., piping, instrumentation, mass balance, electrical, safety, ventilation, etc.) information.  The employer must document that the equipment complies with generally accepted good engineering practices.  In the event that the applicable standards or practices are no longer in use, the employer must document that the equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested and operating in a safe manner.

 

Process Safety Information:     (Continued)

An index of all required PSI should be developed including the location of the master files and controlled copies.

This written PSI shall be compiled prior to performing a process hazard analysis.

The full requirements for Process Safety Information are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(d) and 40 CFR Part 68.65.  This facility?s PSI procedures are defined in the Company?s Compliance Program.

Process Hazard Analysis 

Employers must perform a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in accordance with generally accepted methodologies [i.e., What If Analysis, Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA), Hazard and Operability (HAZOP), etc.] for each covered process.

Employers must also ensure that PHA teams have the required expertise, and that a system is established to address their findings and recommendations.  The PHA shall be performed by a team with expertise including:

?    Engineering and process operations

?    One (1) employee who has experience and knowledge specific to the process being evaluated 

?    A member of the team must be knowledgeable in the specific process hazard analysis methodology being used

This system must also document PHA team resolutions, actions to be taken, and the schedule for planned actions.  The system must also ensure that actions are taken as soon as possible and that they are communicated to employees whose work may be affected.

PHAs must be revalidated and updated once every five (5) years.  Employers must retain records of the PHAs, their updates, and resolutions of recommendations for the life of the covered process.

The full requirements for PHA are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(e) and 40 CFR Part 68.67.  This facility?s PHA procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.

 

Operating Procedures

The employer must develop, implement, and update written operating procedures for each regulated process, including steps for each operating phase (i.e., startup, shutdown, emergency, and temporary operations), operating limits, safety procedures, and health and safety considerations.  These operating procedures must be readily accessible to employees associated with the covered process.

The employer must review these procedures as necessary and certify annually that the written operating procedures are current and accurate.

The full requirements for operating procedures are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(f) and 40 CFR Part 68.69.  This facility?s operating procedures are located in the Company?s Compliance Program.



Training

Employers must provide formal initial and refresher training [at least every three (3) years] for all employees working in regulated processes that include an overview of the process and operating procedures, hazards, emergency response procedures, and safe work practices applicable to their work.  Employers must also document that each employee has received and understands the required training.

The full requirements for training are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(g) and 40 CFR Part 68.71.  The facility?s training programs are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.



Maintenance

The employer must develop, implement, and update written maintenance procedures for each regulated process, including steps for each operating phase (i.e., startup, shutdown, emergency, and temporary operations), operating limits, safety procedures, and health and safety considerations.  These operating procedures must be readily accessible to employees associated with the covered process.

The employer must review these procedures as necessary and certify annually that the written maintenance procedures are current and accurate.

The full requirements for maintenance procedures are stated in 40 CFR Part 68.73(b).  This facility?s maintenance procedures are located in the Company?s Compliance Program.

 

Maintenance     (Continued)

The date of the most recent equipment inspection or test:_______________

The equipment that was inspected or tested (list equipment):_____________

Management of Change

The employer must develop written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and facilities.  This procedure must address the technical basis for the change, impacts of health and safety, modifications to procedures, required time for changes, and authorization requirements for the changes.  Both physical and procedural changes need to be included.  

Employees affected by the change must be informed and receive the proper training.  Any changes in written PSI or operating procedures resulting from the change must be updated.

The full requirements for management of change are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119 (l) and in 40 CFR 68.75.  This facility?s MOC procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.

Contractors

Employers must evaluate safety performance before contractor selection, develop safe work practices, inform contractors working near covered processes of related hazards, explain applicable portions of the emergency action plan, periodically evaluate contractor performance, and maintain a contractor injury and illness log.

Contract employers must provide assurance that their employees received the proper training and understand potential hazards and the relevant portions of the emergency action plan.  Contract employers must also document that each contract employee has received and understands the required training, follows the safe work practices of the facility, and advise the contract employee of any unique hazards.

The full requirements for contractors are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(h) and in 40 CFR 68.87.  This facility?s contractor procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.

 

Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR)

Employers must perform Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) on new or modified facilities to ensure that equipment and construction meet design specifications; that all required procedures and training have been implemented and that hazard analysis recommendations have been resolved.  The PSSR process should specify what authorization and approvals are required before startup can commence.

The full requirements for pre-startup safety review are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(i) and in 40 CFR 68.77.  This facility?s PSSR procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.



Mechanical Integrity

The employer must maintain, inspect, and test critical process equipment in a documented program.  Written procedures, training, and construction Quality Assurance/Quality Control (QA/QC) programs are also necessary.  Inspections and tests of equipment must be documented.  Types of equipment include pressure vessels and storage tanks; piping systems (including piping components such as valves); relief and vent systems and devices; emergency shutdown systems; controls (including monitoring devices and sensors, alarms, and interlocks) and, pumps.  For the construction of new plants and equipment, the employer will assure that equipment as it is fabricated is suitable for the intended process application. 

The full requirements for mechanical integrity are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119(j) and 40 CFR Part 68.73.  This facility?s mechanical integrity program is outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program. 

Hot Work Permit

Employers must implement a formal authorization and permit program for welding and brazing activities near or around covered processes. Requirements for flammable vapor testing and monitoring should be specified.

The full requirements for hot work are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119 (k) and in 40 CFR 68.85.  This facility?s hot work permit procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.

 

Incident Investigation

Employers must investigate incidents that did or could have resulted in a catastrophic release.  Incident investigation must begin within 48 hours and involve a team that includes the appropriate expertise.  A report must be prepared for each incident that includes root cause analysis and recommendations.  The employer must also develop a system to address findings and recommendations of these reports.  Reports must be reviewed with all affected personnel, resolutions and corrective actions must be documented, and investigation reports must be retained for five (5) years.

The full requirements for incident investigation are stated in 40 CFR Part 68.81.  This facility?s incident investigation procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.



Emergency Planning and Response

The OSHA rule relies mainly on previous regulations for emergency action plans and training (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.120).  The plan must also include procedures for handling small releases. The EPA?s RMP rule allows a facility to evacuate and not actively respond to accidental releases, provided that the facility is included in the community emergency response plan developed under 42 U.S.C. 11003 (EPCRA; Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act) and that appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.  While the EPA RMP rule allows the use of plans and programs developed under prior emergency regulations, it stipulates that the plan include items required under the statute, notably procedures for informing the public and local responders about a release.

The full requirements for emergency planning and response plan are stated in 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart E.  This facility?s emergency planning and response plan is outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.



Compliance Audits

Audits must be conducted to determine compliance of the procedures and practices with the RMP standard, and a report of the audit findings must be developed.  The employer must then document a response to each finding and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  Compliance audits must be completed at least once every three (3) years to verify that the program elements are in place and that they have been effectively implemented.  The two (2) most recent reports must be retained.

The full requirements for compliance audits are stated in 40 CFR Part 68.79.  This facility?s compliance audit procedures are outlined in the Company?s Compliance Program.



Trade Secrets

According to the PSM regulation, employers must make all necessary information available to those persons responsible for compiling PSI, performing PHAs, developing operating procedures, investigating incidents, preparing emergency plans, and conducting compliance audits.  The PSM regulation notes that employers may require persons that receive this information to enter into confidentiality agreements

With regards to the Risk Management Plan, the RMP regulations provide guidance for the assertion and substantiation of confidential business information.

The full requirements for trade secrets under PSM are stated in 29 CFR 1910.119 (p).  The full requirements for confidential business information under RMP are stated in 40 CFR 68.151 and 152.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies:

Chesapeake Energy has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility's processes. The Chesapeake policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of substances.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:

Chesapeake operates the Smokehouse Compressor Station located in Logan County, West Virginia. Natural Gas enters the facility via inlet pipeline. Gas is routed to the Plant's natural gas compressor where it is compressed and travels through a coalescing filter. The filter removes any entrained oils in the gas stream and routes liquids to the pipeline liquids storage tank for proper disposal. The gas then travels to a refrigerated dew point plant, a metering system and routed to the pipeline.  The collected liquids are routed to three (3) 30,000 gallon storage tanks and taken by truck to Mark West Hydrocarbons.



Five Year Accident History:

The Smokehouse Compressor Station has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Smokehouse Compressor Station. Because plant processes are subject to EPA's RMP regulations and to OSHA's PSM standards, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



Employee Participation:

Chesapeake and the Smokehouse Compressor Station actively encourage all levels of employees and contract employees to participate in creating a safe work environment. This participation begins with well-established mechanisms of co

mmunication with all employees regarding covered process information. Employees are involved in maintaining PSM rule compliance based on their knowledge, skill, job responsibilities and experience.



Process Safety Information (PSI):

Chesapeake maintains written information intended to provide a foundation for identifying and understanding the process hazards. This information addresses chemical properties, inventories, and associated hazards, as well as design basis/configuration information for key process parameters. Specific departments within the plant are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in the Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented, when required, by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. In addition, the plant has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters and ensures limit maintenance by using highly trained personnel, process controls, and monitoring and protective instrument systems. The plant also maintains documentation that provides information about the design and construction of process equipment. Equipment information includes construction materials, design pressure, and temperature and electrical ratings. 



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

The Smokehouse Compressor Station has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. 

The Smokehouse Compressor Station primarily uses the What-If and HAZOP techniques to perform these evaluations. This technique is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard ev

aluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience, as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process, as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

The PHA team findings are promptly and systematically addressed. The Smokehouse Compressor Station Smokehouse Compressor Station assures that the recommendations are documented and resolved in a timely manner. This documentation includes the actions to be taken and a written schedule of completion dates. The plant also provides proof of communication with operating, maintenance, and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate from the original design safety features, the plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five (5) years by the PHA team.



Operating Procedures:

The Smokehouse Compressor Station maintains written Operating Procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as:

(1)    Initial startup.

(2)    Normal operations.

(3)    Temporary operations.

(4)    Emergency shutdown.

(5)    Emergency operations.

(6)    Normal shutdown.

(7)    Startup following a turnaround or after an emergency shutdown. 

These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a consistent training basis for new operators. Operating procedures are periodically reviewed and certified as current. When a process change occurs, operating procedures are revised as necessary through the management of change process.



Training:

To complement the written process-operation procedures, the Smokehouse Compressor Station has implemente

d a comprehensive training program for all employees. New employees receive job specific basic training in plant operations. Employee training includes emphasis on safety and health hazards, emergency shutdown operations, and safe work practices. Operators demonstrating adequate knowledge to safely perform duties and tasks are allowed to work independently.



 

Hot Work Permit:

The Smokehouse Compressor Station issues a hot work permit for all hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process. The Smokehouse Compressor Station provides Hot Work Permit training to all plant employees. Copies of issued work permits are maintained in Operations and Maintenance for a period of one (1) year following completion of work.



Contractors:

The Smokehouse Compressor Station periodically uses contractors to perform maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovations, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:

(1)    Are trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform their job. 

(2)    Have received and understood the training required and carry a training document card while on location. 

(3)    Follow the safety rules of the location including the safe work practices. 

(4)    Advise the plant of any unique hazards presented by the contractor. 

(5)    Notify the facility of all illnesses and injuries that occur in the process areas.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs):

The Smokehouse Compressor Station conducts a PSSR for any facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides an additional check to make sure that construction and equipment are in accordance with design specification, that adequat

e safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place, and that training of each employee involved in operating the process or equipment has been completed. A standard checklist is used to document compliance.



Mechanical Integrity

The Smokehouse Compressor Station has well-established programs, procedures and practices that are required to ensure that equipment used to process, store, or handle lightly hazardous chemicals and/or flammable gas or liquid is designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of a release. Equipment examples include vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, and relief and vent systems with associated emergency shutdown systems and controls (i.e., monitoring devices, sensors, alarms, and interlocks). Maintenance personnel receive training on:

(1)    An overview of the process. 

(2)    A review of the process hazards. 

(3)    The procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks to ensure that the employees can perform the job tasks in a safe and satisfactory manner. 

Process equipment inspection and testing follows recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices. Equipment deficiencies that are outside of acceptable limits are corrected before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to ensure safe operation.



 

Management of Change (MOC):

The Smokehouse Compressor Station has a comprehensive system to manage and document changes to all covered processes. A systematic approach is followed to control and manage facility changes in order to minimize the possibility that such changes will have an adverse impact on personnel safety, equipment, or the environment. Employees involved in process operations and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks might be affected by process changes are informed of and trained in the change prior to process start-up.



Incident Investigation:

The Smokehouse Compressor Station promptly investigates all incid

ents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. An incident investigation is initiated as promptly as possible to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. This investigation is lead by an incident investigation team consisting of those with appropriate knowledge and experience in the process. The findings and recommendations made by the incident investigation team are promptly addressed and resolved in a timely manner. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.



Emergency Planning and Response:

The Smokehouse Compressor Station retains a written site specific formal emergency response plan which includes the designated actions the company and all personnel will take to ensure personal safety from fire and other emergencies. The plan outlines actions that company technicians and contract employees are to take when there is an unwanted release of highly hazardous chemicals. The intent of this plan is to facilitate the prompt evacuation of employees when necessary and to account for all personnel. The emergency plan also includes procedures for handling small releases.



Compliance Audits:

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is properly functioning, the Smokehouse Compressor Station periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three (3) years. The audit team includes those knowledgeable in the process, operations personnel, and at least one person trained in audit techniques and practices. The audit team develops findings and corrective actions are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, a

nd the two most recent audit reports are retained.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Chesapeake is committed to operating the Smokehouse Compressor Station in a safe manner for workers, the public, and the environment. Chesapeake personnel utilize auditing processes to ensure the plant complies with safe operations of its processes. In the event improvements in safety can be realized through auditing efforts, actions are planned and instituted to respond to safety enhancements of operating practices. Improvements to safety are a continual process at the plant.
